repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Transport and Territorial
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport and
            Territorial Development Project (TTDP) for Haiti were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            informing and sensitizing beneficiaries, and explaining the
            project execution strategy, is required if populations are
            to take full project ownership. Combining road
            rehabilitation (or other infrastructure improvement) with
            local investments can improve the impact of the former and
            stimulate local development. Strong cooperation between
            development organizations such as the Bank, Agence Francaise
            de Developpement (AFD), and the European Union (EU) can be a
            factor of success especially in the context where leadership
            and donor coordination by the government is weak. As part of
            project design, the provision of resources to address
            emergency issues is required in post-conflict and
            disaster-prone countries. Improved transport conditions in
            rural areas translate into better access to markets by
            producers, hence increasing income-generating opportunities;
            they also translate into improved access to social services
            (health, education). A work strategy focused on small and
            medium enterprises (SMEs) for transport infrastructure can
            act as a catalyst for developing private sector activities
            and generating employment. Gravel roads can be a sustainable
            and cost-effective technical solution to improve rural
            transport infrastructure. Improving road maintenance
            services in a volatile environment like Haiti which suffered
            a total collapsing of its national systems in place in the
            nineties is very challenging and a medium long term issue.
            Participatory planning and inclusion can ensure better
            targeting of resources while better responding to community
            needs. Infrastructure subprojects of the type included in
            TTDP component two should present an operation and
            maintenance (O and M) strategy and attendant training program.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Transport and Territorial
            Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Haiti Transport and Territorial Development Project, which
            improves the roads linking smallholders to markets,
            anticipates environmental risks associated with the project
            and recommends measures to mitigate them. Likely
            environmental impacts include topsoil erosion, slope
            instability, road embankment erosion, landslides,
            degradation of road surfaces, sedimentation from drainage
            systems, groundwater contamination from construction works,
            increase in water turbidity, water flow changes, soil
            compaction and pothole formation, loss of forest cover and
            its regeneration, dust from traffic, disruption of animal
            habitats due to traffic and water contamination, risk of
            traffic accidents, resurgence of sexually transmitted
            diseases and tuberculosis, limits to access and interference
            with commercial activities, and modification of the
            countryside, among others. To ensure the sustainability of
            the project, the report recommends establishing an
            information network to ascertain the effect of runoff on the
            most important river basins and to monitor the hydraulics of
            the rivers; limiting the use of heavy equipment during set
            hours; setting speed limits for vehicles; locating works at
            sufficient distance from residences, health centers, and
            water sources; reducing dust, getting approval for site
            locations; restoring the site after construction ends,
            reforesting the site and replacing vegetation; collecting,
            transporting and disposing of waste in an approved manner,
            using stabilizing measures for slopes; reducing the risk of
            accidents; educating the community about disease spread,
            particularly sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS;
            avoiding encroaching on protected areas and critical
            habitats; taking all precautions to preserve water sources;
            notifying the community about traffic interruption in
            advance, sensitizing them about road safety, and using
            signs; accelerating construction to minimize time needed to
            disrupt the community; and in general abiding by
            Haiti's rule on road rehabilitation.

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Transport and Territorial
            Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Transport and
            Territorial Development Project for Haiti is: 'lower
            the marketing costs for small farmers in two selected
            micro-regions and rebuild selected infrastructure in areas
            struck by natural disasters.'  The changes follow the
            occurrence of the series of hurricanes and tropical storms
            that struck Haiti in 2007 and 2008, causing major damages,
            particularly on transport infrastructure. The Haitian
            Government and International Development Association (IDA)
            have identified the Transport and Territorial Development
            Project as a possible vehicle to channel funds for
            reconstruction works. The amendments to the projects grant
            agreement aim at reallocating project resources to these
            reconstruction activities, by creating a new component
            entitled 'post natural disasters' reconstruction
            of selected infrastructure', with a total financing
            amount of US$8 million. Initial project activities will be
            kept unchanged. Provided country environment and project
            performance allow for it, an additional financing will be
            processed in late FY09 or early FY10 to compensate for this
            reallocation and allow all initial activities to be
            financed. This additional financing may also cover any
            possible increase of the price of road works, following the
            increased cost of gasoline. If an additional financing
            cannot be processed, a second restructuring, involving
            substantial modifications of the initial result framework,
            will be processed.
